quizData.question: Packets are forwarded to neighbor routers at once.
quizData.answer: The statement is FALSE . -- Packets are forwarded hop by hop
choices: The statement is FALSE . -- Packets are forwarded hop by hop
The statement is FALSE . -- Packets cannot be forwarded.

quizData.question: What are used only when packets to be forwarded do not match any routing entry in an IP routing table?
Which statement is correct about default routes?
quizData.answer: A packet that matches no routing entry other than the default route is forwarded to an address mapped to the default route.
choices: A packet that matches no routing entry other than the default route cannot be forwarded to an address mapped.
A packet that matches no routing entry other than the default route is forwarded to an address mapped to the default route.
A packet that matches no routing entry other than the default route is forwarded to an address mapped to the static route.
A packet that matches no routing entry other than the default route is forwarded to an address mapped to the nearest route.

quizData.question: If no default route is available, IP packets that do not match any routing entry will be silently discarded.
choices: The statement is FALSE . -- IP packets that do not match any routing entry will be forwarded to static routes.
The statement is FALSE . -- IP packets that do not match any routing entry will be forwarded to default routes.
Pass. Di to kasama sa nireview ko.

quizData.question: Routers and computers always have a default route stored in their IP routing table.
quizData.answer: The statement is FALSE . -- Routers and computers may or may not have a default route stored in their IP routing table.
choices: The statement is FALSE . -- Routers and computers may or may not have a default route stored in their IP routing table.
The statement is FALSE . -- Routers and computers need to configure the default route stored in their IP routing table before using.

Commonly used distance vector routing that uses its routing metric to determine the best route or shortest path.
These routes are used only when packets to be forwarded do not match any routing entry in an IP routing table.

quizData.answer: These routes cannot adapt to link changes.

These routes can adapt to topology changes.
These routes are used only when packets to be forwarded do not match any routing entry in an IP routing table.

choices: These routes can be automatically discovered and learned.

To use these routes on any device, you must manually configure them.
These routes are used only when packets to be forwarded do not match any routing entry in an IP routing table.

quizData.answer: These routes can adapt to topology changes.

quizData.question: It refers to disturbances in that energy to travel through a medium from one location to another.
It refers to the horizontal distance of a wave from a point to the corresponding point on the next wave. This is measured in meters (m) in SI.

It refers to a vertical distance from a given point on the wave from the horizontal axis. In layman’s terms, it is the height above and below the x-axis. This is measured in volts, amperes, or watts, depending on the
type of signal.
It describes the position of the waveform relative to time zero; it is a measurement of the delay of the wave relative to some fixed reference point or another sine wave.

It refers to the number of waves made per second or as cycles per second. It is the reciprocal of the period to complete one (1) wave cycle. The unit for frequency is in Hertz (Hz); 1 Hz means 1 cycle per second (cps).
This refers to the amount of time (expressed in seconds) required to complete one (1) full cycle.
It is a wave in which both the amplitude and time continuously vary over their respective intervals that results in a wavy characteristic.
It is a wave with several discrete (jumpy) states, such as high or low, and on or off. It has fixed amplitude, but its pulse width and frequency can be changed.

What is a schematic description of a network arrangement, connecting various nodes through lines of connection?
What is a type of topology where the computers are connected to a single hub through a cable?

Which topology best describes the advantage?
Advantage: New nodes can be easily added to the network. Communication data must be forwarded by the central node, which facilitates network monitoring
What is a type of topology where a hub is the central node while all other nodes are connected to it.

Which topology best describes the disadvantage?
Disadvantage: Faults on the central node affect the entire network's communication.
What is a type of topology where a network type in which every computer and network device is connected to a single cable?
What is it called when a hub has exactly two endpoints?

Which topology best describes the advantage?
Advantage: The installation is simple and cable resources are saved.

Which topology best describes the disadvantage?
Disadvantages: A cable fault affects the communication of the entire network.

Which topology best describes the advantage?
Advantage: Generally, the failure of a node does not affect the communication of the entire network.

Which topology best describes the disadvantage?
Disadvantages: The information sent by a node can be received by all other nodes, resulting in low security.
What is the type of topology where each computer connected to another computer, and the last one connected to the first—exactly two neighbors for each device?

Which topology best describes the advantage?
Advantage: Cables resources are saved.

Which topology best describes the disadvantage?
Disadvantage: It is difficult to add new nodes. The original topology must be interrupted before new nodes are inserted to form a new topology.
What is the type of topology where it has a root node and all other nodes are connected to it forming a hierarchy?
What is the type of topology is also called hierarchical topology?
How many levels should a tree topology have at least?

Which topology best describes the advantage?
Advantage: Multiple star networks can be quickly combined, facilitating network expansion.

Which topology best describes the disadvantage?
Disadvantage: A fault on a node at a higher layer is more severe.
What is the type of topology where each node or device has a point-to-point connection to other nodes or devices, ensuring that all network nodes are connected?
What is the type of topology where some systems are connected in the same fashion as mesh topology, but other devices are only connected to two or three devices?

Which topology best describes the advantage?
Advantage: The cost of this topology is lower than that of a full-mesh network

Which topology best describes the disadvantage?
Disadvantage: The reliability of this network is lower than that of a full-mesh network.
What is the type of topology where each node or device is connected?

Which topology best describes the advantage?
Advantage: It has high reliability and high communication efficiency.

Which topology best describes the disadvantage?
Disadvantage: Each node requires a large number of physical ports and interconnection cables. As a result, the cost is high, and it is difficult to expand.
What is the type of topology where it consists of a mix of two (2) different types of topologies merging as one network?
In actual networking, multiple types of topologies may be combined based on the cost, communication efficiency, and reliability requirements.

Telecom operators' communication lines use HDLC and PPP.
What is a descriptive network scheme?
What describes the process of information or data traveling from application programs through a network medium to another application program located on another network?
What is the OSI layer that is closest to the user?
What layer provides network services to the user’s applications such as spreadsheet programs, word processing programs, and bank terminal programs?
What layer establishes the availability of intended communication partners, synchronizes, and establishes agreement on procedures for error recovery and control of data integrity?
What layer ensures that the information that the application layer of one (1) system sends out is readable by the application layer of another system?

What layer translates between multiple data formats by using a common format. Provides encryption and compression of data.
Examples: JPEG, MPEG, ASCII, HTML?
What layer defines how to start, control and end conversations between applications, and also synchronizes dialogue between two (2) hosts’ presentation layers and manages their data exchange
What layer regulates information flow to ensure end-to-end connectivity between host applications reliably and accurately?
What layer segments data from the sending host’s system and reassembles the data into a data stream on the receiving host’s system?
What layer defines end-to-end delivery of packets?
What layer defines how routing works (identifying endpoints) and how routes are learned so that the packets can be delivered?

What layer defines how to fragment a packet into smaller packets to accommodate different media?
Examples: Routers operate at Layer 3 - IP, IPX, AppleTalk.
What layer provides access to the networking media and physical transmission across the media and this enables the data to locate its intended destination on a network?
What layer provides reliable transit of data across a physical link by using the Media Access Control (MAC) addresses?

What layer is concerned with network topology, network access, error notification, ordered delivery of frames, and flow control?
Examples: Ethernet, Frame Relay, FDDI
What layer deals with the physical characteristics of the transmission medium?
What layer defines the electrical, mechanical, procedural, and functional specifications for achieving, maintaining, and deactivating the physical link between end systems?

What layer defines such characteristics as voltage levels, the timing of voltage changes, physical data rates, maximum transmission distances, physical connectors, and other similar attributes?
Examples: EIR/TIA-232, RJ45, NRZ.
What is a networking model with a set of communication protocols for the Internet and similar networks?
OSI Model is commonly known as TCP/IP because its Transmission Control Protocol and Internet Protocol (IP) were the first networking protocols defined in this model?
What provides basic communication in TCP/IP Model?
What provides key functions that applications need in TCP/IP Model?
What layer in TCP/IP Model represents an interface through a variety of protocols that enable services to be applied to end-user application processes?
What layer in the TCP/IP model includes services such as handling high-level protocols, issuing representations, encoding, and dialog control?
What layer in the TCP/IP model is responsible for reliable end-to-end data delivery from the source host to the destination host?

What layer in the TCP/IP model is responsible for the delivery of service requests that respond from the transport layer and have them arrive at their destination through the “virtual network” image of the Internet?
What layer in the TCP/IP model is also called the host-to-network layer, which is concerned with all of the issues that an IP packet requiresto make a physical link to the network media?
The network interface layer functions include mapping the IP addresses to physical hardware addresses and encapsulation of IP packets.
Which layer in the OSI model is considered Layer 7?
Which layer in the OSI model is considered Layer 6?
Which layer in the OSI model is considered Layer 5?
Which layer in the OSI model is considered Layer 4?
Which layer in the OSI model is considered Layer 3?
Which layer in the OSI model is considered Layer 2?
Which layer in the OSI model is considered Layer 1?
